newsitem.title: CZECH REPUBLIC: PRESS DIGEST - CZECH REPUBLIC - JULY 23.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - CZECH REPUBLIC - JULY 23.

text.p: HOSPODARSKE NOVINY - The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development signed a contract yesterday to invest capital of 1.1 billion crowns into the domestic radiator maker Korado. This is its second largest investment ever outside of banking and infrastructure.

- The European Commission of the EU obtained letters from the Czech and Polish governments requesting aid in overcoming catastrophic floods. The commission is prepared to meet with both countries to discuss relief methods.

- June results for the trade deficit were relatively good, although the trade deficit for the first half of the year is 74.4 billion crowns. Growth in exports exceeded growth in imports, and the trade deficit in June was 9.6 billion crowns. Some analysts expect this year's trade deficit to be lower than last year's.
- Ministers decided yesterday that during privatisation of the state's stakes in energy distribution companies, there will be a possibility for their managers to obtain small stakes.
- The crown strengthened yesterday after positive results of the June trade balance. It closed at 19.045 against the mark and 34.485 against the dollar.
- According to EBRD director for the Czech Republic and Slovakia Jiri Huebner, the city of Ostrava could obtain a loan from the EBRD to overcome flood damages.

- Plzensky Prazdroj and Becherovka want to privatise 89 percent of Becherovka through the newly established company B-Prit, which has only Czech capital. Prazdroj holds 66 percent, and BELUP, established by Becherovka's management, has 34 percent.

MLADA FRONTA DNES - According to reports from individual ministries, it seems that total damages caused by the floods will not be more than 50 or 60 billion crowns, counting losses in production and customers. Finance Minister Pilip said some estimates may be inaccurate.
- The cabinet should make a definite decision today on which eight Czech embassies should be closed due to budget cuts. Among these are embassies in Kuwait, Yemen, Albania, Uruguay and in Vietnam.
- According to a survey from STEM, 44 percent of Czechs are in favour of early elections, while 54 percent are against them.
- The management of Jihoceske Mlekarny, the largest milk processor in the country, will purchase a 50.3-percent majority stake directly from IPB Group.
- From August 1, flood bonds will be available at seven banks -- Investicni a Postovni Banka, Ceska Sporitelna, CSOB, Komercni Banka, Union Banka, Zivnostenska Banka and Hypobanka.

- During a meeting of ministers yesterday, it was decided that Finance Minister Ivan Pilip will meet with the Governer of the Czech National Bank and Slovak partners to resolve property shares of Slovak subjects in Komercni Banka and Ceskoslovenska Obchodni Banka. Ceska Sporitelna should also be privatised soon, and IPB bank should be sold in one month.
PRAVO - From today, Ceskomoravska Hypotecni Banka, in an attempt to help citizens affected by the floods, will begin an express system to process reguests for mortgages within seven working days.
- The cabinet will decide today over increasing patients' payments by 100 percent, which was proposed last week.
- According to a July survey from STEM, the most popular politician is the vice-chairwoman of CSSD, Petra Buzkova, followed by Stanislav Gross, Josef Zieleniec and Milos Zeman.
LIDOVE NOVINY - Skoda Mlada Boleslav will increase its prices for all cars except the cheapest Felicia, which it will leave at 219,000 crowns.
- Yesterday, the central bank decreased its one-week and two-week repo rates by 0.3 percentage points to 15.7 percent.
- According to a survey from IVVM, 26 percent of Czechs trust the cabinet, up four percent over June.
- President Vaclav Havel, who is currently on holiday at his cottage, will visit flooded areas in the next few days.
-- Prague Newsroom, 420-2-2423-0003
